In reference to Chris Stutz's article on Dr.
Marshall McLuhan, let me first say that Mr. Stutz is
a fine writer. Next,let me say that Mr. Stutz greatly
underestimates his own intelligence.

T o the Editor:
All persons (and that does include JHU freshmen)
arc entitled to certain unalienable rights, among
them the right of peaceful elimination. With the
recent Freshmen elections, however, this right has
been totally disregarded.
I, for one, take exception to being bombarded
with "Boldness, Reliability and Broad-mindedness
when simply trying to carry out those natural
functions spurred by Servomation food. Is nothing
sacred? Has even the bathroom, the one place
throughout history where a person could truly be at
peace, become an appropriate arena for political
propaganda?
And what of the future? Must we expect to find
candidates' promises squeezing out of paper towel
dispensers? Will we soon discover campaign rhetoric
scrawled on toilet paper rolls?
The practice of bathroom brainwashing signals a
pathetic state of affairs here at the John. Ironically,
it seems that political propaganda may finally have
found its rightful place in the world:hanging around
all the other crap.

The article begins with an accurate, yet only
partial, indictment of the vagaries and
inconsistencies of Dr. McLuhan's presentation. It
then makes an admirable attempt to bestow order
on the speaker's ramblings succeeding to the point
of improving upon the quality of the actual speech
itself. One does get the impression, however, that
in order to have made such sense from the event, he
had frequently to resort to encyclopedia
compendiums for further explanations of the
individuals and phenomena with which Dr.
McLuhan so liberally laced his talk.
Unfortunately, Mr. Stutz's characterization of Dr.
McLuhan as "brilliant" betrays a certain naivete of
intellectual judgment. This is due to the fact that he
holds the value of popular notions and fads above
that of individual judgment. For, judging by the
quality of his presentation, Dr. McLuhan's success is
directly attributable to his prescience in selecting a
field for study which lends itself to superficial
hyping by some 'popular opinion' makers for the
purpose of mass consumption.
Dr. McLuhan manages to befuddle his audience
by discussing numerous intriguing phenomena
without giving the slightest idea of what they may
have in common with each other. By virtue of his
reputation, he leaves us with the feeling of
inadequacy at not having been able to detect an
underlying theoretical structure to his teachings.
Instead of turning our scorn upon the speaker, we
direct it against ourselves. Fearing dreadfully at not
being "with it," we turn around and further
perpetuate the myth of Dr. McLuhan by lauding his
"brilliance."

Graf-Jacobson Duo One of Best
by J.V. Considine
The Peabody-Hopkins concert series got off 'to a
roraring start when pianists Enrique Graf and Katherine
Jacobson performed a duo-piano recital in Shriver Hall
October 1.
Duo-piano recitals are far from commonplace
occurances these days, and one suspects this is due as
much from the somewhat limited repertoire as it is from
the logistics problem of getting two matched concert
grands on the stage at the same time. Surely, there is
literature available for one piano, four hands, but it would
be foolish to restrict a concert bill to strictly those pieces.
Is it any wonder, then, that there are but few great
piano duos in the world today? Alfons and Aloys
Kontarsky, Eden and Tamir, and Walter and Beatriz Klein
are a few of the great duos, and to those pairs we should
add yet another; Graf and Jacobson.
Mr. Graf and Ms. Jacobson are both master students of
Leon Fleisher, the famed pianist who teacher at the
Peabody. Their ensemble performances date back to a
Faculty recital in 1976 (both were on the faculty of the
Preparatory Department).That performance was so
successful that the duo was sponsored by the Peabody in
the National Piano Ensemble Competition this year,
which they won by unanimous decision of the judges.
Having heard them play, one is not surprised. The two
pianists do not play exactly alike; rather, like the
different sections of an orchestra, they maintain certain
distinct timbraltraits, which greatly enhance the sound of
the duo. One hears a sense of depth and shading that
exemplifies the best in pianistic technique, but, because
of the use of two pianists, the colorisms are expanded on
a grand scale.
In this respect, one wishes that the two pianos used in
the concert had been better matched. The primary piano
was the magnificent German Steinway used by the Shriver
Hall Concert Series. Regrettably, the secondary piano,

which was not a bad piano in itself, was so outclassed by
the magnificence of sound and clarity of tone generated
by its German brother, that the two instruments seemed
almost like the prince and the pauper. This problem was
avoided at first, as the opening piece in the concert was the
Mozart Sonata in C Major. (K.521) for four hands. With
Ms. Jacobson carrying the bass while Mr. Graf effortlessly
delivered the treble, it was a performance of unmistakable
grace and sheer Mozartean clarity. One felt that, with an
opening of such infinite delight, the duo would be
hard-pressed for a rejoinder.
Hard-pressed, perhaps, but successful nevertheless,
for following the Mozart was a stunning reading of
Beethoven's Sonata 8 in c minor (op. 13), "Pathetique,"
by Mr. Graf.
An extreme, yirtuosic sense of dynamics, an insightful
sense of phrase and robust sense of Romanticism
characterized Mr. Graf's performance. Tossing off phrase
after phrase with almost frightening abandon, Mr. Graf
gave the impression that even the most difficult passages
were mere child's play for him.
In fact, perhaps the only criticism one might have was
that Mr. Graf's playing seemed almost athletic in its sense
of technical prowess. The piano was often pushed to its
limits, its rich sonority verging on clangor.
But one need only recall that Beethoven was well
known for his pianistic excesses, and his inability to find
in those puny Viennese pianos a suitable outlet for his
powerful technique. With this in mind, one seemed to get
an idea of what the Pathetique sounded like for
Beethoven, its edges rough and sonorities surging, as Mr.
Graf eschewed the almost overly polite playing of many
concert pianists.
Following the Beethoven was the Brahms Variations on
a Theme be Haydn (op. 56), for two pianos. The work
seems to be a Peabody favorite, as the Peabody orchestra
had performed it a mere four days before. Although the
orchestral version is by far the more popular, one finds
that the piano score is ,not, only an easier means of
following the piece's exposition, and, because of its

lighter tone, generally more pleasing. The performance
easily did justice to both composer and composition.
Alexander Scriabin was a Russian prodigy, whose piano
and orchestral music infused a strong sense of mysticism
into a Spartan, if somewhat spatial, romantic esthetic. His
Sonata in f minor (op. 23), which was performed by Ms.
Jacobson, is a technically intriguing work, somehow
reminiscent of later Liszt, yet not entirely rewarding to
the listener.
Thus, it was ample tribute to Ms. Jacobson that she
maintained a cogent sense of lyricism that kept the
listener's interest while remaining true to the ephemeral
spirit of the work. In short, a convincing performance of a
less-than- convincing work.
Finally, the audience was treated to Ravel's La Valse. A
truly orchestral duet, it is better known to most audiences
in its later orchestral version. Despite the general fondness
of American audiences for orchestral Ravel, one can easily
come to believe that it is through the piano works that he
is truly to be known
The Graf-Jacobson Ravel was truly a knowing
performance in that respect, despite having been marred
by the unequal balance between the two instruments.
Previously, Mr. Graf's powerful, crisp playing had
previously graced only the German Steinway, while Ms.
Jacobson,performed the Brahms on its American cousin.
The difference was not as noticable then, because Ms.
Jacobson's playing was more fluid, less intense than that
of Mr. Graf, and thus did not tax the American piano.
Both piano parts in the Ravel demand the utmost from
their pianos, and thus some of Mr. Graf's rippling glissandi
demanded more than his poor keyboard could deliver. In
Ravel, the clarity is of tantamount performance,so such a
failure was unfortunately irritating.
Ourtisde of such technical trivialities, though, the
performance of the Ravel was admirably authoritative,
and delightfully crisp. If this concert is indicative of what
the Peabody has to give Hopkins, certainly many will be
eagerly awaiting the next offering.

The Spanish poet Vicente Aleixandre, this
year's Nobel
prizewinner, was born in Seville (Andalusia) in 1898
and
spent his childhood in Malaga, the Meditterrane
an city
which is the source of inspiration for many of his
poems.
Aleixandre only discovered poetry when he was
almost
20, and in 1928 published his first book, written
during an
illness that kept him away from his work as an economist
(Aleixandre has been chronically suffering from renal
tuberculosis). For years he lived in Madrid in close
relationship to the poets of his generation (Garcia Lorca,
Alberti, Guillen,Cernuda...), tcthe, Chilean Pablo Neruda
and the younger Miguel Hernandez. One of his -worst
health crises kept him in this city[ after the Civil War, and
because of his obviously Republican allegiance his
namecould not even be printed during the first years of
the Franco regime. In 1949 he was elected a member of
the Spanish Royal Academy of Language. Aleixandre has
been the most influential living figure in the development
of Spanish poetry, having also been read in Latin r,
America.
His work (12 books of poems) is remarkable for its
sustained quality and for a surprising capacity for
constant evolution. Aleixandre's early writing combines
the Post-Symbolist tradition withtthe game-like fashion of
the early 9's avantgarde, but very soon he turned to a
strongly irrational, almost oneric language close to
Surrealist "automatic writing." The poetry of his middle
period has been characterized as a Neo-Romantic
"pantheist mysticism: the vision of the cosmos as a
creative exotic impulse that thends to unity through its
own destruction. During the 50's, Aleixandre humanized
reality in very simple poems about history, about' human
time; about the individual's difficulties in living.
His very recent work (for most critics his best by far)
constitutes an impressive exploration of time, knowing,
experience, and old age in an extremely dense language.

the National Piano Ensemble Competition this year,
which they won by unanimous decision of the judges.
Having heard them play, one is not surprised. The two
pianists do not play exactly alike; rather, like the
different sections of an orchestra, they maintain certain
distinct timbraltraits, which greatly enhance the sound of
the duo. One hears a sense of depth and shading that
exemplifies the best in pianistic technique, but, because
of the use of two pianists, the colorisms are expanded on
a grand scale.
In this respect, one wishes that the two pianos used in
the concert had been better matched. The primary piano
was the magnificent German Steinway used by the Shriver
Hall Concert Series. Regrettably, the secondary piano,

which was not a bad piano in itself, was so outclassed by
the magnificence of sound and clarity of tone generated
by its German brother, that the two instruments seemed
almost like the prince and the pauper. This problem was
avoided at first, as the opening piece in the concert was the
Mozart Sonata in C Major. (K.521) for four hands. With
Ms. Jacobson carrying the bass while Mr. Graf effortlessly
delivered the treble, it was a performance of unmistakable
grace and sheer Mozartean clarity. One felt that, with an
opening of such infinite delight, the duo would be
hard-pressed for a rejoinder.
Hard-pressed, perhaps, but successful nevertheless,
for following the Mozart was a stunning reading of
Beethoven's Sonata 8 in c minor (op. 13), "Pathetique,"
by Mr. Graf.
An extreme, yirtuosic sense of dynamics, an insightful
sense of phrase and robust sense of Romanticism
characterized Mr. Graf's performance. Tossing off phrase
after phrase with almost frightening abandon, Mr. Graf
gave the impression that even the most difficult passages
were mere child's play for him.
In fact, perhaps the only criticism one might have was
that Mr. Graf's playing seemed almost athletic in its sense
of technical prowess. The piano was often pushed to its
limits, its rich sonority verging on clangor.
But one need only recall that Beethoven was well
known for his pianistic excesses, and his inability to find
in those puny Viennese pianos a suitable outlet for his
powerful technique. With this in mind, one seemed to get
an idea of what the Pathetique sounded like for
Beethoven, its edges rough and sonorities surging, as Mr.
Graf eschewed the almost overly polite playing of many
concert pianists.
Following the Beethoven was the Brahms Variations on
a Theme be Haydn (op. 56), for two pianos. The work
seems to be a Peabody favorite, as the Peabody orchestra
had performed it a mere four days before. Although the
orchestral version is by far the more popular, one finds
that the piano score is ,not, only an easier means of
following the piece's exposition, and, because of its

lighter tone, generally more pleasing. The performance
easily did justice to both composer and composition.
Alexander Scriabin was a Russian prodigy, whose piano
and orchestral music infused a strong sense of mysticism
into a Spartan, if somewhat spatial, romantic esthetic. His
Sonata in f minor (op. 23), which was performed by Ms.
Jacobson, is a technically intriguing work, somehow
reminiscent of later Liszt, yet not entirely rewarding to
the listener.
Thus, it was ample tribute to Ms. Jacobson that she
maintained a cogent sense of lyricism that kept the
listener's interest while remaining true to the ephemeral
spirit of the work. In short, a convincing performance of a
less-than- convincing work.
Finally, the audience was treated to Ravel's La Valse. A
truly orchestral duet, it is better known to most audiences
in its later orchestral version. Despite the general fondness
of American audiences for orchestral Ravel, one can easily
come to believe that it is through the piano works that he
is truly to be known
The Graf-Jacobson Ravel was truly a knowing
performance in that respect, despite having been marred
by the unequal balance between the two instruments.
Previously, Mr. Graf's powerful, crisp playing had
previously graced only the German Steinway, while Ms.
Jacobson,performed the Brahms on its American cousin.
The difference was not as noticable then, because Ms.
Jacobson's playing was more fluid, less intense than that
of Mr. Graf, and thus did not tax the American piano.
Both piano parts in the Ravel demand the utmost from
their pianos, and thus some of Mr. Graf's rippling glissandi
demanded more than his poor keyboard could deliver. In
Ravel, the clarity is of tantamount performance,so such a
failure was unfortunately irritating.
Ourtisde of such technical trivialities, though, the
performance of the Ravel was admirably authoritative,
and delightfully crisp. If this concert is indicative of what
the Peabody has to give Hopkins, certainly many will be
eagerly awaiting the next offering.

The Spanish poet Vicente Aleixandre, this
year's Nobel
prizewinner, was born in Seville (Andalusia) in 1898
and
spent his childhood in Malaga, the Meditterrane
an city
which is the source of inspiration for many of his
poems.
Aleixandre only discovered poetry when he was
almost
20, and in 1928 published his first book, written
during an
illness that kept him away from his work as an economist
(Aleixandre has been chronically suffering from renal
tuberculosis). For years he lived in Madrid in close
relationship to the poets of his generation (Garcia Lorca,
Alberti, Guillen,Cernuda...), tcthe, Chilean Pablo Neruda
and the younger Miguel Hernandez. One of his -worst
health crises kept him in this city[ after the Civil War, and
because of his obviously Republican allegiance his
namecould not even be printed during the first years of
the Franco regime. In 1949 he was elected a member of
the Spanish Royal Academy of Language. Aleixandre has
been the most influential living figure in the development
of Spanish poetry, having also been read in Latin r,
America.
His work (12 books of poems) is remarkable for its
sustained quality and for a surprising capacity for
constant evolution. Aleixandre's early writing combines
the Post-Symbolist tradition withtthe game-like fashion of
the early 9's avantgarde, but very soon he turned to a
strongly irrational, almost oneric language close to
Surrealist "automatic writing." The poetry of his middle
period has been characterized as a Neo-Romantic
"pantheist mysticism: the vision of the cosmos as a
creative exotic impulse that thends to unity through its
own destruction. During the 50's, Aleixandre humanized
reality in very simple poems about history, about' human
time; about the individual's difficulties in living.
His very recent work (for most critics his best by far)
constitutes an impressive exploration of time, knowing,
experience, and old age in an extremely dense language.
